Title:
Monography and the PhyloCode: a practical example from the
moss clade Leucophanella
Abstract:
Here I present a cladistically based monograph of a group
of closely related mosses known as the Syrrhopodon involutus complex.
Monographs remain a critical and indispensable component of systematics,
but traditional monographic practices require some revisions if modern
monographs are to truly reflect and incorporate phylogenetic
understanding. I summarize the methods used to address issues relating
to sampling and the formation of OTUs for this monograph, and emphasize
the importance of incorporating morphological character data in a total
evidence phylogenetic analysis. In addition to a traditional Linnaean
taxonomic treatment, I provide rank-free definitions of the terminal
taxa in the S. involutus complex. Following the PhyloCode
recommendations for the designation and naming of more inclusive taxa, I
present a novel method for naming terminal taxa as least-inclusive
clades. This monographic treatment represents a first attempt at
applying the PhyloCode at the terminal level in any plant group, and
recognizes five distinct taxa in the S. involutus complex, which I have
designated with the rank-free clade name Leucophanella: banksii,
borneensis, involutus, rufescens, and revolutus.
